headline.print_headline: Don’t Know Who You Are, But Don’t Know Who I Am
headline.main: Don’t Know Who You Are, but Don’t Know Who I Am

results.snippet: In Duncan Jones’s science-fiction film, a man who knows himself to be a helicopter pilot wakes up on a train traveling to Chicago, only to find he is in someone else’s body.
results.lead_paragraph: In Duncan Jones’s science-fiction film, a man who knows himself to be a helicopter pilot wakes up on a train traveling to Chicago, only to find he is in someone else’s body.

headline.main: Kristin Fisher, Walker Forehand

results.snippet: The bride and bridegroom met in Athens on a summer study abroad program.
results.lead_paragraph: Kristin Anne Fisher, a daughter of Dr. Anna L. Fisher and Dr. William F. Fisher, both of Houston, was married Saturday to Walker Harrison Forehand, the son of Margaret Peters Stalnaker of White Stone, Va., and Judge V. Thomas Forehand Jr. of Chesapeake, Va. The Rev. James H. Burch of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy City in Washington. The bride and bridegroom, both 27, met in Athens in 2003 on a summer study abroad program.

results.abstract: Jose Arguelles, the father of mammoth New Age event Harmonic Convergence, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline.main: José Argüelles, New Ager Focused on Time, Dies at 72

results.snippet: Mr. Argüelles organized the Harmonic Convergence, which drew thousands of adherents to sites around the globe and also focused the popular imagination the Mayan calendar.
results.lead_paragraph: José Argüelles, the father of the Harmonic Convergence, the mammoth New Age event that in 1987 drew thousands of humming adherents to sites around the globe, died in the Australian bush on March 23, not much more than a year before the world, in his view, might well have ended anyway. He was 72 and lived in Ashland, Ore. His death, from peritonitis, was announced on the Web site of the Foundation for the Law of Time, an organization he founded. The group seeks to rescind the modern Gregorian calendar, which Mr. Argüelles deemed dangerous, and replace it with one rooted in ancient astronomy.

headline.main: Russia: Rocket Launch Marks 50 Years of People in Space

results.snippet: Final preparations were underway Monday evening at the Baikonur space center to launch a rocket in honor of the 50th anniversary of the flight of the first person in space, Yuri A. Gagarin.
results.lead_paragraph: Final preparations were underway Monday evening at the Baikonur space center to launch a rocket in honor of the 50th anniversary of the flight of the first person in space, Yuri A. Gagarin. Two Russian cosmonauts and an American astronaut are scheduled to ride the Yuri Gagarin rocket into orbit, on their way to the International Space Station; the honorary naming was a departure from the usual Russian practice of numbering rockets. The rocket, scheduled to launch before Tuesday, also has a portrait of Mr. Gagarin painted on the side. He was only 27 years old when he made his first and only journey into space, and he later died in a jet airplane crash. The Soyuz model booster was being fueled Monday evening on the same launch pad where Mr. Gagarin blasted off on his flight on April 12, 1961, which began with his words ''Let's go.''

headline.main: Space Junk Safely Passes Space Station; Crew OK

results.snippet: After monitoring a small piece of space junk for 11 hours, NASA determined it posed no danger Tuesday to the International Space Station and its three residents.
results.lead_paragraph: After monitoring a small piece of space junk for 11 hours, NASA determined it posed no danger Tuesday to the International Space Station and its three residents.

results.abstract: Eve M Kahn Antiques column notes forthcoming documentary and exhibition by Mark Forgy and Colette Loll Marvin on hidden life of art forger Elmyr de Hory both titled Elmyr de Hory: The Art and Science of Deception; discusses documentary and exhibitions of midcentury modern British textiles fostered by husband-and-wife team H Kirk Brown III and Jill A Wiltse; reports Sotheby's will auction artifacts from Soviet space program. Photos (M)

headline.main: Gleaning the True Identity Of an Enigmatic Forger

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: ELMYR DE HORY: THE ART AND SCIENCE OF DECEPTION (MOVIE)

results.snippet: Mark Forgy has been poring over the archive of Elmyr de Hory, a Hungarian-born painter known for forging works who died in 1976, to uncover his real identity.
results.lead_paragraph: Elmyr de Hory, a Hungarian-born painter known for forging works by Picasso, Modigliani and Matisse, was the subject of biographies and documentaries full of his own lies about his background. In 1976, while under investigation for art fraud, he committed suicide by overdosing on sleeping pills, leaving behind boxes of paperwork that are now yielding some truths. Mark Forgy (pronounced FOR-ghee), a writer in suburban Minneapolis who was Mr. de Hory's assistant and housemate on Ibiza in the 1970s, inherited the archive. He has been poring over it with Colette Loll Marvin, an art historian in Paris. They are conducting interviews and tracking down government records to update a Web site and to produce a documentary and exhibition, both titled ''Elmyr de Hory: The Art and Science of Deception.''

headline.main: Spare Times: For Children

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for, by and about kids in New York.
results.lead_paragraph: 'REVOLTING RHYMES' Any poetry that includes the lines ''In the kitchen, peeling spuds,/Cinderella heard the thuds/Of bouncing heads upon the floor'' might justifiably be called revolting. But severed heads aside, this and other children's verses by Roald Dahl are revolting in another way. They strike a rebellious blow against the prettified world of simpering princesses, predictable princes and monsters that somehow turn out to be cuddly. Dahl's Little Red Riding Hood packs a pistol; his Goldilocks belongs in juvenile court (how many nice little girls do you know who break into houses?); and his Crocky-Wock the Crocodile, cute name notwithstanding, ''likes to crunch/six juicy children for his lunch.''

headline.main: He Can Sing It, If Not Speak It

results.snippet: BILL CALLAHAN'S ''Apocalypse'' is a record that knows itself. Mr. Callahan, 44, one of our best lyricists and now -- finally -- a singer approaching excellence, uses his voice carefully, in a no-vibrato baritone, going down to Merle Haggard's range....
results.lead_paragraph: BILL CALLAHAN'S ''Apocalypse'' is a record that knows itself. Mr. Callahan, 44, one of our best lyricists and now -- finally -- a singer approaching excellence, uses his voice carefully, in a no-vibrato baritone, going down to Merle Haggard's range. His recent songs have the pace of a more confiding time in music, when singer-songwriters in Nashville and Los Angeles were first working out what male sensitivity sounds like. ''Apocalypse'' can resemble an early-1970s record by Gordon Lightfoot or Mickey Newbury, but more heavy-hearted, slowed down by a quarter, with far fewer chords, and with words that embody rather than explain. Its lyrics form a bestiary: cattle, hog, bee and buffalo are all here, as well as the phrase ''work's calving increments and love's coltish punch.'' It works the phrase ''my apocalypse'' into the fourth and seventh songs, which are the first and last tracks of the album's second side in its vinyl version. Its last lyric, sung twice and meaningfully, is ''DC 450'': the catalog number of the album, released last week on the label Drag City.

results.abstract: NASA chooses final destinations for three space shuttles; Discovery will go to Smithsonian, Endeavour to California Science Center and Atlantis to Kennedy Space Center; photos (M)

headline.main: NASA Chooses Space Shuttles' Retirement Homes

results.snippet: Shuttles that have been carrying astronauts for 30 years were assigned to their final destinations: Florida; Los Angeles; Washington, D.C.; and Manhattan.
results.lead_paragraph: NASA's space shuttles, which have been carrying astronauts aloft for 30 years, were assigned to their final destinations on Tuesday: one will head to the nation's capital, another to Los Angeles, and the third from its current home at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to the center's visitor complex next door. In a ceremony commemorating the shuttle program, Maj. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., the NASA administrator, made the long-awaited announcement of where the soon-to-be museum pieces would end up.

results.lead_paragraph: 3:22 p.m. | Updated President Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttle Endeavour, and perhaps join Representative Gabrielle Giffords if she is able to watch as her astronaut-husband, Mark E. Kelly, leads the mission into space, administration officials confirmed on Wednesday.

results.abstract: Pres Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttle Endeavour, and perhaps join Rep Gabrielle Giffords as her astronaut-husband, Capt Mark Kelly, leads the mission (S)

headline.main: First Family Will Look Up

results.snippet: 3:22 p.m. | Updated  President Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttleEndeavour, and perhaps join Representative Gabrielle Giffords if she is able to watch as her astronaut-husband, Mark E. Kelly, leads the...
results.lead_paragraph: 3:22 p.m. | Updated President Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttleEndeavour, and perhaps join Representative Gabrielle Giffords if she is able to watch as her astronaut-husband, Mark E. Kelly, leads the mission into space, administration officials confirmed on Wednesday. Ms. Giffords, the Democratic congresswoman from Tucson who suffered a brain injury in the shootings there on Jan. 8, is hoping to be on hand, friends and staff have said. Her husband is the commander of the shuttle mission, which leaves from Cape Canaveral, Fla. She has been receiving rehabilitative therapy in Houston.

headline.main: Spare Times

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for, by and about children and teenagers in New York.
results.lead_paragraph: EARTH DAY AT THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN While many children will hunt for Easter eggs this weekend, those visiting the New York Botanical Garden on Friday will seek other treasures. These won't have anything to do with candy or the Easter Bunny, though a rabbit might appreciate the leafier discoveries.

results.abstract: Members of NASA's astronaut corps are wondering what is next, now that the space shuttle program is ending; over the next few years, American astronauts will be competing for a handful of slots on the International Space Station, flying there on Russian Soyuz capsules; photos; chart (M)

headline.main: With 'Coolest Job Ever' Ending, Astronauts Seek Next Frontier

results.snippet: As the space shuttle program comes to an end, it is a time of great uncertainty for those whose job involves spaceflight.
results.lead_paragraph: What happens when you have the right stuff at the wrong time? Members of NASA's astronaut corps have been asking just that, now that the space shuttle program is ending and their odds of flying anywhere good anytime soon are getting smaller. The Endeavour is scheduled to launch this week, and the Atlantis is supposed to fly the last shuttle mission in June -- and all the seats are spoken for.

headline.main: What's On Today

results.snippet: 10 P.M. (National Geographic) THE ANGEL EFFECT Near death as he and two companions trekked for 36 hours over the mountains and glaciers of the sub-Antarctic South Georgia Island, the explorer Ernest Shackleton later wrote, ''It seemed to me often...
results.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (National Geographic) THE ANGEL EFFECT Near death as he and two companions trekked for 36 hours over the mountains and glaciers of the sub-Antarctic South Georgia Island, the explorer Ernest Shackleton later wrote, ''It seemed to me often that we were four, not three.'' Years later a 9/11 survivor, an astronaut and a scuba diver would each tell a strikingly similar story about a mysterious presence that guided them to safety in their time of peril. A phantom? An angel? Or a trick of the mind? This ''Explorer'' edition uses recent neurological research -- on subjects like this student, above -- to investigate the phenomenon called ''the third-man factor,'' experienced by hundreds of people. The documentary is based on the book ''The Third Man Factor: Surviving the Impossible,'' by John Geiger, who is an author, with Owen Beattie, of ''Frozen in Time: The Fate of the Franklin Expedition'' and the president of the Royal Canadian Geographical Society. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS The seven remaining celebrities discuss what they'll need to do to reach the finals, while the judges and former contestants offer criticism. Hanson and the cast of ''Rock of Ages'' perform. The sixth-round results show, at 9, features New Kids on the Block, the Backstreet Boys and the recent ''American Idol'' castoff Pia Toscano.

results.abstract: Rep Gabrielle Giffords will attend her husband Capt Mark E Kelly's shuttle launching in Florida (M)

headline.main: Crowd to Join as Giffords Views Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: Family, friends, aides, health workers and the president will join Representative Gabrielle Giffords as she watches her husband return to space on Friday.

byline.original: By MARC LACEY; Denise Grady contributed reporting from New York, and James C. McKinley Jr. from Houston

results.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX -- Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who has been given the green light by doctors to attend her astronaut-husband's shuttle launching on Friday afternoon, will be joined at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida by family, friends, aides and health workers -- not to mention President Obama and his family -- as the space shuttleEndeavour lifts into space. Ms. Giffords's mother plans to attend, and her father might as well. Two aides who were injured along with Ms. Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, when a gunman opened fire outside a constituent event in Tucson on Jan. 8 will also attend, officials said.
